meanings.definition: Preserve (a body) by embalming and wrapping in cloth.
meanings.sent1: The ancient Egyptians would mummify their pharaohs to keep them safe for the afterlife.
meanings.sent2: After the funeral, they decided to mummify the deceased to honor their memory.
meanings.sent3: I accidentally spilled juice on the paper, so I tried to mummify it with a towel.
meanings.sent4: The old photographs were mummified in a dusty album, preserving memories of the past.
meanings.sent5: The chef's secret recipe was carefully mummified in a sealed jar to protect it from prying eyes.

meanings.definition: To make (a dead body) into a mummy by embalming and drying.
meanings.sent1: The archaeologists discovered a tomb where they could mummify the ancient remains.
meanings.sent2: In the museum, visitors can see how experts mummify bodies to study ancient civilizations.
meanings.sent3: The kids pretended to mummify their friend with toilet paper during a game of make-believe.
meanings.sent4: The desert heat naturally mummified the remains, preserving them for centuries.
meanings.sent5: The artist used special techniques to mummify the sculpture, giving it a timeless quality.

meanings.definition: To preserve (an object) by drying and wrapping in cloth or bandages.
meanings.sent1: To save the fragile artifact, they decided to mummify it in layers of protective material.
meanings.sent2: The explorer carefully mummified the ancient scroll to prevent it from decaying further.
meanings.sent3: The students tried to mummify their science project with tape and tissue paper.
meanings.sent4: The tradition of mummifying important documents dates back to ancient times.
meanings.sent5: The museum curator knew how to mummify delicate textiles to ensure their longevity.
